index.html.title: 0. Home
index.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-home" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15 21v-8a1 1 0 0 0-1-1h-4a1 1 0 0 0-1 1v8"></path><path d="M3 10a2 2 0 0 1 .709-1.528l7-5.999a2 2 0 0 1 2.582 0l7 5.999A2 2 0 0 1 21 10v9a2 2 0 0 1-2 2H5a2 2 0 0 1-2-2z"></path></svg>
index.html.description:
KireiSakura-Kit is a library written in Bash for making powerful shell scripts.
Written in purely bash, can be used in POSIX* shell script. Modular, import only stuff you need. Log support, with various levels. Many in-built methods, no need to write from scratch. Various UI elements.
See TODO for upcoming features.
Docs Repo
index.html.author: soymadip

terminology.html.title: 1. Terminologies
terminology.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-book-a" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M4 19.5v-15A2.5 2.5 0 0 1 6.5 2H19a1 1 0 0 1 1 1v18a1 1 0 0 1-1 1H6.5a1 1 0 0 1 0-5H20"></path><path d="m8 13 4-7 4 7"></path><path d="M9.1 11h5.7"></path></svg>
terminology.html.description:
1st, let's understand some terms used throughout the Docs.Methods are the functions exposed by Modules. They are the primary API for interacting with KireiSakura-Kit. Modules are self-contained scripts that store methods. Each module performs a specific task and can be sourced as needed. There are 3 types are modules:-These are essential components of the KireiSakura-Kit providing the foundational functionality required for the framework to operate. These are automatically loaded at start. These are optional modules used to extend the functionality of the framework.
These are required to be loaded implicitly using kimport function.
These are similar to plugin modules except these are designed & implemented by the user.Info Create user modules by making a directory called modules in the project root. <PROJECT_ROOT> |-main.sh |-modules/ | |-module1.sh |-module2.sh KireiSakura-Kit defines several key environment variables, known as Super Variables, which store important paths and project-related information. Super Variables start with kirei_. Currently there are below super vars: - kirei_docs_url → URL to the official documentation. kirei_project_name → Name of the project. kirei_dir → Root directory of KireiSakura-Kit. kirei_core_dir → Directory containing core scripts. kirei_core → Path to the main entry script. kirei_module_dir → Directory containing additional modules. kirei_assets_dir → Directory for assets like icons and themes. kirei_cache_dir → Directory for caching temporary files. kirei_log_file → Path to the log file for debugging and tracking.
Done Now that you know the terms, head to Initialization to start sourcing Kit.
terminology.html.author: soymadip

init.html.title: 2. Initialization
init.html.description:
Warning Although Kit is stable enough now Things are subject to change as this project is in beta stage . Frequent changes are being made until stable release. # Required export PROJECT_NAME="Project Name" # Optional export CACHE_DIR="/path/to/cache/dir" export LOG_FILE_NAME="log_file_name" Some variable(s) must be exported at the very top of your script, even before sourcing KireiSakura-Kit. It provides essential metadata that the kit uses during setup.Specifies the name of your project. ⚠️ KireiSakura-Kit won't start without this one. Default: NULL (Kit will throw an error if not set.) Defines the directory path where KireiSakura-Kit will store temporary files. Default: If $XDG_CONFIG_HOME is set: $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/<project name> Otherwise: ~/.config/<project name> Specifies the name of the log file. The log file will be created at: <CACHE_DIR>/<LOG_FILE_NAME>.log Default: <PROJECT_NAME>.log Prerequisites Make sure you have curl, grep installed. Install figlet too for the header. (optional) Add below lines to your script. This will check if KireiSakura Kit is installed or download & source the kit:-if command -v kireisakura &> /dev/null; then eval "$(kireisakura --init)" else clear -x && echo echo "> Downloading KireiSakura-Kit" curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/soymadip/KireiSakura-Kit/refs/heads/install/install.sh -o kirestaller.sh bash kirestaller.sh -ds fi you can also only install KireiSakura Kit in your system Run this command in your terminal:- curl -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/soymadip/KireiSakura-Kit/refs/heads/install/install.sh | bash -s By default KireiSakura Kit only imports core modules.Modules are imported using kimport method. To import plugin modules:- #import specific modules kimport disk-utils change-shell enable-os-prober #import all modules at once kimport -a
To import user modules use -l flag:- kimport -l module1 module2 module3 #to import all modules kimport -l -a
Done Now that Initialization is complete, you can use methods to build script.
init.html.author: soymadip

methods.html.title: 3. Methods
methods.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-webhook" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M18 16.98h-5.99c-1.1 0-1.95.94-2.48 1.9A4 4 0 0 1 2 17c.01-.7.2-1.4.57-2"></path><path d="m6 17 3.13-5.78c.53-.97.1-2.18-.5-3.1a4 4 0 1 1 6.89-4.06"></path><path d="m12 6 3.13 5.73C15.66 12.7 16.9 13 18 13a4 4 0 0 1 0 8"></path></svg>

faq.html.title: 4. FAQ
faq.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-circle-help" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><circle r="10" cy="12" cx="12"></circle><path d="M9.09 9a3 3 0 0 1 5.83 1c0 2-3 3-3 3"></path><path d="M12 17h.01"></path></svg>
faq.html.description:
Officially supported:Bash & Zsh Other POSIX-compliant shells should work but are not officially tested. However, any fixes will be accepted. When all planned features for initial release will be completed. Whole point of this framework is to simplify, beautify shell scripting. Even though some methods are basically one line command, they are hassle to write or getting correctly, having method drastically simplifies that. For the methods:-
Browse the source code in starting from core dir Functions have comments showing how to use them (like args, flags, output etc..). For the Docs:-
Clone this repo. Install obsidian.
Open the notes as a obsidian vault. It contains plugins, settings. Edit the notes & submit PR, it will be checked & accepted. Generate site code:-_ Optionally,
Install obsidian-webpage-export plugin. Then export to html using obsidian-webpage-export form the ribbon to the docs directory of the cloned repo.

headers.heading: 2. When will stable version be released?
3. Why are there are methods for one line commands?

faq.html.author: soymadip

todo.html.title: 5. TODO
todo.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-circle-dot" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><circle r="10" cy="12" cx="12"></circle><circle r="1" cy="12" cx="12"></circle></svg>
todo.html.description: Make init.sh in kit root for initialisation. Make setup command: eval "$(kireisakura --init)" Make other commands: kireisakura -h kireisakura -v kireisakura -d kireisakura -i. kireisakura -u Make a test script. Make install script. Better directory structure. Revamp project. Better directory structure. Clearer naming conventions. Make old Modules compatible. Implement Auto-Update. Make a clearer Design guide. Make use of log file in more functions (for more detailed logs). Check if core functions & dependency functions are loaded and set that script load flag true using a variable. Config file support. toml as format? use of YQ? Add -q or --quiet flag to all possible functions. Write documentation (help needed). Enable completions (still thinking if useful): Make script. Source the file. In install script: printf "echo \"fpath+=(\"${kirei_dir}/completions\")\" >> \"${zsh_rc}\""
todo.html.author: soymadip

maintainance.html.title: maintainance
maintainance.html.description: body { height: 100vh; display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; margin: 0; background-color: var(--surface0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; } .popup-overlay { position: fixed; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; } @keyframes popup { 0% { transform: scale(0.5); opacity: 0; } 100% { transform: scale(1); opacity: 1; } } .box { padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; background-color: var(--base); border: 2px solid var(--maroon); box-shadow: 0 4px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2); text-align: center; width: 400px; position: relative; animation: popup 2s ease-out; } .box img { max-width: 100px; height: auto; } h1 { font-size: 2.1rem; color: #f5b193; margin: 0; } h2 { font-size: 1.4rem; color: var(--text); margin: 20px 10px; margin-bottom: 5px; } p { font-size: 0.7rem; color: var(--teal); margin: 0; } a { color: inherit; text-decoration: none; } </style> [ We will be back soon ]

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
